Cohort study
Participants are divided into groups based on the presence or absence of a critical exposure and are evaluated for differences between the groups in the development of a disease or outcome

Participants may be recruited before the outcome of interest develops and followed forward in time (prospective cohort) or recruited and grouped according to exposure at a time when the outcome would have already occurred (retrospective cohort)

Prospective cohort: Women in the first 5 years after menopause onset who are receiving estrogen therapy are compared with women not receiving estrogen therapy. All are assessed yearly over 10 years of follow-up for the development of cognitive impairment

Retrospective cohort: Postmenopausal women who received estrogen replacement therapy in the first 5 years after menopause onset are compared with those who did not receive estrogen with respect to development of dementia. Women who experienced menopause 10 or more years ago are included in the study
May provide the highest level of evidence for diagnosis or prognosis studies
Useful for studying rare exposures, outcomes that develop over time, and survival (time-to-event analyses)
Provides true incidence of disease
Risk for recall bias with retrospective cohort design
Risk for participants to be lost to follow-up in prospective studies with lengthy follow-up intervals
Can be lengthy and expensive to follow participants until they develop disease
Difficult to match both cohorts in all variables except for exposure
Risk ratio (or relative risk): risk for developing the outcome being studied if exposed to the risk factor of interest compared with those who have not been exposed
Case-control study
Participants are divided into groups based on the presence or absence of a disease or condition and compared with respect to past exposures
Mothers of infants with and without a rare congenital heart disease are compared with respect to prenatal exposure to medications suspected of being associated with the disease
May be the only way to collect enough data to meaningfully assess relationships about exposures in rare diseases
Can evaluate multiple exposures
Risk for recall bias, because events being studied have already occurred and participants with disease are more likely than controls to recall past exposures
Difficult to match controls to cases
Cannot determine the true incidence of disease
Odds ratio: odds of having been exposed to the risk factor of interest in those with the condition being studied versus those who do not have the condition
Cross-sectional study
Evaluates the relationship between exposures and health outcomes in a population of interest
Factors and outcomes are measured at a single point in time

Surveys conducted by health services groups may serve as the basis for these studies. Examples include the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey and the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance Survey, both conducted by the CDC
Best used to determine disease prevalence and generate hypotheses
Can also assess the relatedness between two exposures of interest
Cannot be used to determine cause and effect because temporal sequence is unknown and comparison groups are not used

Prevalence ratio (prevalence odds ratio): prevalence of the outcome or condition in individuals with the exposure or risk factor of interest compared with prevalence in individuals without the risk factor
Ecological study
Evaluates the prevalence or extent of an exposure across distinct populations
Comparison of rates of colon cancer in countries with higher versus lower rates of red meat consumption
Used to identify compelling trends for an exposure of interest across different groups, which can be investigated subsequently in more focused studies
Cannot be used to determine cause and effect
Incorrect assignment of causation based on ecologic study results is termed the ecological fallacy
Rate ratio: prevalence of a condition in groups with higher rates of exposure compared to prevalence in groups with lower rates of exposure
